The transform_if function

Source: R/transform_if.R
transform_if.Rd

The transform_if() function transforms an object x, based on the logical result (TRUE, FALSE, NA) of condition function cond(x) or logical vector cond, such that:

  • For every value where cond(x)==TRUE / cond==TRUE, function yes(x) is run or scalar yes is returned.

  • For every value where cond(x)==FALSE / cond==FALSE, function no(x) is run or scalar no is returned.

  • For every value where cond(x)==NA / cond==NA, function other(x) is run or scalar other is returned.

Usage

transform_if(x, cond, yes = function(x) x, no = function(x) x, other = NA)

Arguments

x

a vector, matrix, or array.

cond

either a logical vector, or a (possibly anonymous) function that returns a logical vector.
In both cases the logical vector in question must be of the same length as x.
For example: \(x)x>0.

yes

the (possibly anonymous) transformation function to use when cond(x)==TRUE.
Alternatively, one can also supply an atomic scalar to fill in when cond(x)==TRUE.
If this argument is not specified, yes defaults to function(x)x.

no

the (possibly anonymous) transformation function to use when cond(x)==FALSE.
Alternatively, one can also supply an atomic scalar to fill in when cond(x)==FALSE.
If this argument is not specified, no defaults to function(x)x.

other

the (possibly anonymous) transformation function to use when cond(x) returns NA.
Alternatively, one can also supply an atomic scalar.
If this argument is not specified, argument other defaults to NA.
Note that function other(x) is run or scalar other is returned when cond(x) or cond is NA, not necessarily when x itself is NA.

Value

The transformed vector, matrix, or array (attributes are conserved).

Details

Be careful with coercion! For example the following code:
x <- c("a", "b")
transform_if(x, \(x)x=="a", as.numeric, as.logical)
returns:
[1] NA NA
due to the same character vector being given 2 incompatible classes.

See also

tinyoperations_dry()

Examples

x <- c(-10:9, NA, NA)
object <- matrix(x, ncol=2)
attr(object, "helloworld") <- "helloworld"
print(object)
#>       [,1] [,2]
#>  [1,]  -10    1
#>  [2,]   -9    2
#>  [3,]   -8    3
#>  [4,]   -7    4
#>  [5,]   -6    5
#>  [6,]   -5    6
#>  [7,]   -4    7
#>  [8,]   -3    8
#>  [9,]   -2    9
#> [10,]   -1   NA
#> [11,]    0   NA
#> attr(,"helloworld")
#> [1] "helloworld"
y <- 0
z <- 1000
object |> transform_if(\(x)x>y, log, \(x)x^2, \(x)-z)
#>       [,1]          [,2]
#>  [1,]  100     0.0000000
#>  [2,]   81     0.6931472
#>  [3,]   64     1.0986123
#>  [4,]   49     1.3862944
#>  [5,]   36     1.6094379
#>  [6,]   25     1.7917595
#>  [7,]   16     1.9459101
#>  [8,]    9     2.0794415
#>  [9,]    4     2.1972246
#> [10,]    1 -1000.0000000
#> [11,]    0 -1000.0000000
#> attr(,"helloworld")
#> [1] "helloworld"
object |> transform_if(object > y, log, \(x)x^2, -z)
#>       [,1]          [,2]
#>  [1,]  100     0.0000000
#>  [2,]   81     0.6931472
#>  [3,]   64     1.0986123
#>  [4,]   49     1.3862944
#>  [5,]   36     1.6094379
#>  [6,]   25     1.7917595
#>  [7,]   16     1.9459101
#>  [8,]    9     2.0794415
#>  [9,]    4     2.1972246
#> [10,]    1 -1000.0000000
#> [11,]    0 -1000.0000000
#> attr(,"helloworld")
#> [1] "helloworld"
